line.en: The old garage was built in a hidden part of the\nschool grounds.
It seems like no one uses it and it's seen by\nalmost no one.
I thought there might be something interesting in\nthere, so I sneaked inside.
The first time I saw it, I just thought, 'There's\nsome weird object in here' and I wasn't too\ninterested in it.
The thing that changed everything... was finding\nthat photo.
Hidden carefully inside a notebook, there was an\nincredibly beautiful photograph of the clouds.
Could such a beautiful sky really exist!?
It was so amazing that I felt myself asking that.
But, it's strange.
What's with this photo...?
Ah, I got it!!
Yes, this photo was taken from above the clouds.
That is what was written on the pages between\nwhich it was placed.
'We're so lucky! We, by pure chance, flew on the\nMorning Glory that suddenly appeared above\nKazegaura!'
'This could be considered a miracle. It was an\nunbelievable experience.'
Morning Glory? They flew?
As I continued to read through the notebook... or\nrather, flight log, I became more and more\ninterested.
This photo of the clouds, was taken by the same\npeople who used this garage. They flew above the\nclouds in an aircraft called a glider.
This glider has no engine, and it flies by riding\nthe wind...
How does that feel, to ride on the wind and fly\nthrough the sky?
To soar through that beautiful field of clouds...
When I pondered on that thought, my mind had been\nmade up.
I would repair the abandoned glider, and aim for\nthe distant clouds.
The next day, I immediately revealed my great\nplan to my best friend.
'The sun's starting to set. Do you wanna call it\na day?'
Ageha said that as I was taking a break after\nreturning from a flight.
'We can go one more time, can't we?'
We still have a bit of time before the sun\ncompletely sets.
'There are no street lights around here, so it'll\nbe pretty dark before the sun completely sets.\nThat will make landing dangerous.'
She's right.
Just now when we came back, it was hard to see\nthe runway and my depth of perception was messed\nup.
'So that's why we've finished today. Kotori,\nlet's get going.'
Ageha called Kotori on her cell-phone. Currently,\nKotori is by the winch.
'Are we done for today...?'
'Yeah. Though the perfect wind for training has\njust started blowing.'
'Nothing we can do about that... We don't want to\nhave any accidents.'
Amane looks towards the eastern sky as she\nspeaks.
There, as always, is the same orange glow of\nsunset.
'Looks like the 'sign' didn't appear again...'
The sky indicated that nothing would happen the\nfollowing morning.
I watched her from the side while she looked to\nthe sky, and her face seemed filled with\nimpatience.
Since the winch came back, we've been doing as\nmany test flights as possible, every day.
There are adjustments to be made to the glider,\nbut the main objective is for Amane and I to do\nflight training.
'You were able to fly quite high today. How high\nwas it, roughly?'
'Around 600 meters.'
'Oh, that's the highest so far. You're really\ngetting the hang of this, aren't you?'
'Yeah. But it's still hard to ride the thermals.'
Thermals are vertical drafts formed by air heated\nby the earth's surface.
They occur more easily in areas where the\ntemperature above the ground rises easily, like\nsoil or asphalt.
By catching these thermals, we can fly to higher\naltitudes.
However, the thing we're chasing is the wind,\nwhich is invisible. It's not easy to catch.

Even after riding it well, the wind is
unpredictable. The wind's flow and strength is
not stable -- it may disappear at a moment's
notice.
But if we don't get good at riding it, we won't\nbe able to fly high enough to reach the passage\nof clouds.
Amane looks down with a blank expression, and\nwithout even attempting to eat it, plays with her\npasta with her fork.
'You didn't like it?'
'Huh...? No, ah... it's not that.'
'I've been doing some thinking...'
She gave a faint smile and prodded at her pasta.
I look towards Ageha and shrug.
Kotori was next to Amane, absorbed in reading the\nbook that she had borrowed from the library.
'Why don't you do that after you've finished\neating?'
'Sure...'
It's no good. She's not listening.
Kotori, for a long time, has been finding out\nabout Morning Glory.
Since we started the test flights, Kotori, being\ndisabled, has had nothing to do except operate\nthe winch.
That's why she seems to be thinking 'I'm\nuseless!'.
She was really involved in the construction of\nthe main wings too, so that's not true at all.
But because of this, we found out about something\nimportant.
A few days ago, after the farewell party...
'Hmm... This is about the natural phenomenon that\noccurs in Burketown, Australia.'
Hibari translated from the book written in\nEnglish, after being pestered by Kotori.
It's a book about Morning Glory.
According to this, the clouds that appear above\nAustralia can have a total length of\napproximately 1000 kilometers.
It's not just one cloud that appears, it can be\nmany at the same time.
When the sun comes up, the temperature increases\nand the clouds disappear. There is only about two\nhours before that happens.
For the local people, this is a sign of rain, and\nraging winds blow beneath the clouds.
The altitude of the clouds is about one or two\nkilometers. If you can ride the vertical drafts\nwell, it is possible to reach those altitudes.
'It says that this is caused by a collision of\nthe sea breeze and the land breeze.'
'At night, the air cools and wind speed drops,\nand the inversion layer...'

'If we can understand the mechanisms of it all,
then it's easy to predict. But, Kazegaura has
vastly different terrain and weather conditions
to Australia...'
'Aren't there are any other signs that are easier\nto understand?'
'It has something like that written here.'
Hibari translates as she reads.
'Warm winds blow from the north, and at dusk, the\neastern sky becomes purple.'
'It says that if water droplets appear in the\nfridge at the pub, it will occur.'
'There might be a pub around here!'
'Calm down, this is talking about Australia.'
'It says... That on mornings when the air\ntemperature is low, but the overall temperature\nis high, it often occurs...'
'The air temperature is low but the overall\ntemperature is high, and at dusk on the evening\nbefore, the eastern sky is purple...'
'Wait a second!'
Kotori excitedly opens a page in the old\nnotebook.
It's a flight log written by one of the old\nmembers.
'Hey, look at this.'

Kotori opened it to the page that explained the
signs that were seen on the day the photograph
was taken. In other words, the day that the
Morning Glory had occurred.
It seems that they did a test on that day, and\nthere was detailed information on the weather\nconditions written in the flight log.
'When they did the test at around 4 PM, the air\ntemperature was 23 degrees centigrade... That's\npretty low for the height of the summer.'
'It says 'After that, a strong wind blew from the\ndirection of the sunset, and it was chilly.''

This was written in the remarks column. They went
to the effort of writing it, so that must mean
that there was quite a big change in air
temperature.
'As for the color of the sky... it doesn't say.'
The important thing is, the log was written\nwithout the knowledge that 'Today, Morning Glory\nwill occur'.
They wrote this without realizing that this was a\nsign of the Morning Glory.
'This is a pretty big hint, isn't it?'
'Yeah! Thanks, Hibari!'
'Hee hee, don't mention it!'

Since then, Kotori has been checking the weather
forecast every night, and reading books about
weather, like she's trying to become a weather
forecaster or something.
So, the three signs that indicate the coming of a\nMorning Glory are as follows:
1: The day before, a warm, strong wind blows, and\nthe temperature is high enough to cause water\ndroplets to appear on a fridge in a pub.
2: At dusk, on the day before, the eastern sky is\npurple.
3: It's much colder than most summer days.
Perhaps this information isn't just nonsense, and\nthis is all we had to go on.
'Hey, Aoi. Whose turn is it today?'
'I'm not sure.'
Every day, we take it in turns to wake up before\ndawn, to see whether or not those clouds have\nappeared.
Even if there are no signs the day before.

Kotori lifts her head as I say that.
'Yes, it is.'
'It's you, isn't it, Ageha?'
'Huh, is it?'
'Hey, don't try to play dumb.'
'Isn't it Amane?'
'Hmm? Yeah, that's right. It's me.'
'I see. We'll leave it to you, Amane.'
'It's me.'
'I see, so it's you, Aoi?'
'Well then, I'd better quickly have a bath and go\nto bed.'
If the Morning Glory does come, we have to fly\nright away.
That's why we covered the glider on the runway\nand just covered it up with a sheet.
Even if it doesn't occur, we can still start\ndoing test flights from early in the morning.
It's a little rough but it doesn't look like it's\ngoing to rain, so there isn't much we can do.
There's no way we can let this one in a million\nchance pass us by.
